content.description: This slightly stoopid route was hard to pass up for how close it is to the trail head. Good for when you're in West Sedona and don't have a lot of time or for an after work romp. Start with grunting your way through the burly OW to chimney. Follow the path of least resistance up easy terrain and locate the bolt below the summit cap. Clip and and pull a wild mantel move to gain the top. Two bolts with chain anchor
content.location: The mini-spire (not actually a spire) can be seen from the beginning of the Thunder Mountain Trail Head. It will be on your right, below Chimney Rock, as you hike northwest. Take one of the many social trails and some slabs to the base. Total hike time from your car is about 5 minutes lol.

climbs.name: Pocketful of Magic
climbs.fa: Tim Morgan, Garrett Collier, John Knight

content.description: Steep start with a couple tricky moves but pockets magically appear to help you with your ascent. The crux for me was at the third bolt. Move quick to avoid the pump.
content.protection: 9 bolts. Two bolt anchor with courtesy clips.
content.location: Work your way up to the base of Magic Staircase then head up and left for another 5 minutes or so. Look for the rock with the giant pockets.

content.description: A fun route with a series of pumpy moves down low. This route includes a sustained series of pocket pulling down low. Likely no single move over 5.9 but if you don't move quickly it will feel more like 10a. Let me know what you think of the grade. Feels a lot like a gym climb. Simply follow the (closely spaced) bolts and pockets but don't get sucked in to the vortex!While you're there, consider top roping lines to the left and right of this route. I have cleaned them a bit but may still have a few loose flakes so be careful. Happy climbing!
content.location: Starts right of Magic Cactus, just left of the Juniper Tree. Look up for the first bolt about 10' off the ground. For other nearby climbs, check out the map here - Area Map

content.description: Another fun, safe, beginner route. Great lead for a new 5.7 climber. Just follow a series of stair steps to the top.
content.protection: Bolts. Just clip and go. Two bolt anchor on top.
content.location: Follow the directions to the Stupa Crag (Stupa Crag) then work your way left.

content.description: A continuous series of well protected 5.8-ish moves. If you don't get the beta perfect, it may feel more like 5.9. A series of bolts protect all the moves except near the top. You'll need to carry a 1" wide cam and slip it into a pocket near the top of the climb. Without the cam, there is a 15' to 20' runout on 5.7.
content.protection: 9 draws plus a #1 cam near the top.
content.location: From the Thunder Mountain Trailhead parking lot, just follow the Thunder Mountain Trail until you're really close to the rock and then head due north. See main subarea page for more info. on the approach. Once at the rock, look for a "magic" prickly pear cactus. The climb starts right above the cactus and stays right of the dirty corner.

content.description: A fun, beginner route with an easy approach. The route climbs a series of big ledges to a set a bolted anchor at the top. Use long runners to minimize rope drag.
content.protection: Bolts. Just clip and go. Bring long slings to reduce rope drag. There is a 2 bolt anchor on top w/quick links. It's quite a ways past the last bolt on very easy (5.3) ground.
content.location: Find your way to the Stupa Crag (see approach info. here - Stupa Crag) and then work your way left to the lumpy, spire like features. The route starts in a "dark" chimney/slot on the left side of the feature.

content.description: A group of mostly south and southwest facing climbs with an amazingly short (5 minute) approach. This area has a special energy. Maybe it's the Sedona vortexes, maybe it's the nearby Stupa, or maybe it's just an awesome place to be. This subarea offers great views, an easy approach and fun climbing. It will definitely suck you in. There are 3 or 4 established climbs on this feature and many more being developed in the area. If you have a few extra minutes, be sure to stop by the Stupa. It's worth the short detour and may bring you good Karma.
